author: Loki-Don
body:
Yeah, people have been saying this since Jobs died a decade ago. Here is what’s different. 

Last year 54% of all Apples revenue was the iPhone. 10 years ago, it was 82%. 

Last year Apple cleared 50 billion in revenue for services (i cloud services, Apple Music, Warranties etc). 10 years ago that revenue was 7 billion a year. 

Last year Apple cleared 25 billion in wearable, home gear and accessories (Apple TV, WiFi routers, Apple Watch, AirPods etc). 10 years ago that was 3 billion a year. 

Basically, Apple has found 65 billion a year in new revenue sources since Jobs died, and make more money (in real terms) on iPhones than they did 10 years ago. 

They will be fine.

author: irresponsible_owl
body:
I've been holding AAPL since 2007 and I'm up about 1200%. It's a 12 bagger for me. My $10k initial investment is now worth $120k.

It's funny how many people have told me to sell over the years, giving me their idiotic rules of thumb like "sell if it doubles" or "take your original investment out if you're up a lot".

When I enter a position I'm in it for the long haul and I'm not going to sell it unless there's a major change to the company or if I need the money for something else and believe that position is my most over-valued one.

Edit: I will say that if you're trading, you should have your exit strategy planned before you even enter the position. You should have a point where you exit whether it's winning or losing and you should stick to that plan. But the wrong time to figure that out is after you already bought the stock, it moved, and you're trying to figure out what to do. Always have a plan, always stick to your plan. My plan happens to be "hold forever, or until I need to sell to pay for something else".

author: Assume_Utopia
body:
I've lost count of the number of times I've seen this stupid graph compared to stocks charts and "matching up" because of "clever" choice of time frame. It's probably been compared to Tesla's stock chart at least a dozen times in the last couple years.

If you have *any* stock that has a period of very good returns, that aren't straight up (and they never are) you're going to be able to find some part of the chart that matches up with this. That doesn't mean anything, for a few obvious reasons:

* Not every stock follows this trend, in fact most don't. Look at the chart for any stock that's had a great run over a couple years (or more) like Amazon, Apple, Google, FB, MS, etc. And then zoom in and crop it so that it roughly looks like this shape. You'll easily be able to find a number of different spots that fit the "pattern". And in almost all those cases the stock just keeps going up afterwards (because of selection bias), but if you zoom and crop creatively enough you can find this general shape in nearly any stock that's had a long history.
* This specific pattern isn't supposed to be for any arbitrary point in a company's lifecycle, it's for when a company first goes public. Smart money gets in, then institutional money, then the general public gets over excited and then it sells off and goes back to "normal"

For reference here's what TSLA's chart [looked like](https://i.imgur.com/JDEmqyp.png) for the appropriate period in the first couple years after it's IPO. It's kind of tough to tell which of the dips is supposed to be the initial "bear trap", but I suspect if I played with the scale and margins a bit I could make it fit perfectly. At least if we ignore the last bit of the "prediction".

author: TipsyLore
body:
I'll give you an easy to follow beginner friendly guide. Forgive the formatting, I'm on my phone.

1) Start with familiarity, write down a list of companies you see or use during your daily life. These could be Apple, Samsung, McDonald's, Starbucks, Target, Walmart or Tesla. Try to only put companies you are actually familiar with so you have some understanding and confidence in their business. 

2) Look at each companies annual earnings for the past 5 years. Specifically look at their EPS numbers. "Earnings per share" This one number can tell you if the company is profitable or not. Net income/Outstanding Shares = EPS. Now is this one metric trending up or down?

3) Pull up the chart of the good companies from your list that have an EPS that is trending up. Put a 200 and 50 SMA "Simple Moving Average" on the chart. If the 50 is above the 200, the stock is trending up, if the 50 is below the 200 the stock is trending down.

4) Think about your how long you want to be investing. If you plan to be long term investor "5 to 20 years" then there's no point trying to catch the highs or lows, just invest in a company that is profitable and trending up both financially and technically. If you plan on being a swing trader "1 to 6 month" you'll need to have more specific technical analysis.

Good luck.

author: theipd
body:
I am going to be a lot nicer than some are on this.   First why are you buying options with 2-3 day expiration dates?    I answered someone about this last week when an OP asked about avoiding rookie mistakes.     This is the one that gets me every time.    

As a beginner your goal should be making every attempt to get a DELTA  of 1.  Not just the actual delta, but IV, gamma, theta all in sync to make you profit.   

As a beginner you should do paper trading first.   The get rich quick bullshit from WSB isn’t going to get you  there.   Memes have their day but not every day.  

I am not a CPA or financial advisor but I can tell you what I did many years ago.  I read a book called “Options as a Strategic Investment” in my spare time.  I bought silly short term options and got burned on all but may be two.  Like a gambler I kept doing it so that the wins were just covering up the losses.  

After I woke up I then went to Leaps.  Apple leaps to be specific and found over the years, that with every option that I buy it must be at least 3 months out.   If I can afford it I will buy them in the money.  OTM options I will need 6-12 months out.  WHY?   The easiest answer to this is that you neglected gamma and vega in your calc.  That pesky calculus BS that everyone hates.  The low theta was interesting but I’d never trust that with the time frame given.   I prefer not to think about all of this and get rid of a lot of it by buying at least 3 months out.   As a beginner your goal should be to eliminate as many Greek issues that you can.   Buying OTM should be 6-12 months out so that you don’t lose 50% of your investment when the stock drops less that 50 cents.   

Again I don’t want to be rude, these are lessons that we learn as we go.  I hope you didn’t lose too much on thsi play.  If you insist on doing this though you might want to look at SPY options, a lot of short term adrenaline junkies play there.   Good luck.

At $6, Wish is massively undervalued, and current prices are likely driven by a market overreaction to the Q2 earnings report and bearish all around short term market sentiment. I sold my AAPL and TSLA shares and doubled down on Wish today.

author: milanello09
body:
Kudos on investing so early.

Semis are a great industry to park money for the long term, albeit a more volatile industry, it’s one of my favorites.

All the positions you’ve listed are good options. Some more appealing than others.

What I suggest you do is start analyzing alternatives on your own and draw your own conclusions. You can do this by using free sites like finviz.com - filter by sector > technology and industry > semiconductor (there’s 2).

If you just want an opinion; AMAT and AMD are the 2 on my watchlist. TSM is critical, but I feel a bit overvalued at this time. ASML is also up there with the first 2, but the higher price point eliminates it from my strategy. 

Why?  Fundamentally, AMAT is the best > high growth,  ok valuation, critical business to the industry, market leader

AMD for momentum.

GL

author: Swingtrader79
body: Don't buy the ETFs. Most are manufacturers that have reached capacity. That means they now need to spend a lot more money on new equipment to enable them to make more chips. That will weigh on earnings (unless they capitalize the expense), but in either case, they have less cash flow. The real winners in the next year or two are the companies selling these makers the equipment to expand their plants. That's ASML and AMAT. I've got AMAT. I failed to buy ASML foolishly but am waiting for a pullback to get into it. I also recently bought INDI b/c the smaller semis are suddenly getting more business with the big ones over capacity.

Tesla: Proprietary full self driving system:: Macintoshes : Proprietary OSes

author: Traditional-Leader54
body:
If you don’t need the royalty payments now I would suggest looking into a retirement account and just let your money grow over the next 40 years. In the US these are tax deferred until age 55 or 62 depending on the plan. 

If you want the payments now I’d look into dividend stocks. They are stocks that pay you money (I think quarterly) based on how many shares you have and how much money the company made that quarter. Think CocaCola, Microsoft, IBM, Apple, etc. Companies that earn consistently and aren’t going anywhere. This is less risky than investing in a startup company for a true royalty that only lasts if the company does. 

Either way talk to a stock broker for more info.

author: Lyrolepis
body:
The problem is that ten years ago, when your backtest starts, Tesla for example *was* a relatively new company, and it was not at all obvious - except perhaps to some domain experts, possibly, but I'm doubtful - that it would have been so successful. 

> If you don’t feel that the market leaders are going to provide good returns moving forward (which is pretty ridiculous to think)

If it was so obvious that TSLA and the others were going to keep growing (let alone as quickly as they have), their current price would already reflect this (just as the fact that TSLA had a relatively low price ten years ago reflected the fact that it was a relatively risky investment then). 

Remember, there was a time IBM was a "market leader" too, and a wildly successful one too (not the only possible example, only the first one that came to my mind). 

Note, I am not saying that the companies you selected are not going to be successful in the future - for all I know, they could well be. 

I'm not even saying that you should not do that: as you wrote, it's just one euro per day, even in a worst case scenario that's not something that is likely to ruin you (if it *is*, you have bigger worries than investing). But I'm saying that I would not expect your backtest to give reliable estimates on the return of your investment.

author: Goddess_Peorth
body:
Nope, I'm reading it in Firefox on a linux desktop.

Having lots of users doesn't matter. Just like, chrome having lots of users doesn't tell you which is more popular in a certain industry. More people using phones for internet than full computers also doesn't help tell you what people use at work.

Cloud services are only profitable in the business to business uses. Businesses using google cloud are more likely to be doing so because they have small needs, they're not spending money on network services. Businesses who have core business "in the cloud" are using AWS, Microsoft, or IBM. Google can't really tap into that business, because their history of cancelling services means that nobody builds their core business on top of google services. It would be a completely insane thing to do.

Autonomous driving is snake oil, because they're using trained AI. That's a dead end for this use case, because what happens when the Dept. of Transportation tells you, "In XYZ situation, you need to do A B and C and never L M or N." You can't! You don't even know how your software really works with a trained AI. It takes a long time to make small changes. It will never be more than a type of cruise control, until companies bite the bullet and put the programming hours into expert systems. (Source: day job includes writing robotics firmware)

author: shortyafter
body:
You don't have anything like Tesla or ARK funds, which is good.  I'm not deeply familiar with most of these companies, so I don't know what their revenue streams or growth prospects look like.  What I can say is that a lot of those names have been trading very high lately... AMD, Nvidia, TSM, ASML, etc. Those companies in particular all seem to have bright futures, but if there is any significant correction in tech stocks, you're very exposed, especially if you bought recently at high valuations.  You'll have very little margin of safety.

And if there's any broader economic disruption, it's possible that not all of these companies make it out safe and sound, or at least as healthy as you'd like to seem them given current valuations.

For example, even good companies like Cisco didn't make it out in one piece from the dot-com bubble.  And old industry leaders like IBM and Intel have gotten hammered in the past two decades, while Microsoft made something of a surprise comeback after being declared dead around 2012.

The point is that if you've bought growth stories, that's OK, but it seems your whole portfolio is growth stories.  It's forward-looking.  Which is the idea, in a way, but IMO you want at least some of your portfolio dedicated to something that is solid in the present, and doesn't rely on a growth story in order to generate or even maintain returns.  The benefit of an ETF is you get a bit of everything, and even QQQ is quite diversified compared to your portfolio.  

I'm new but this is my understanding of things.  I hope it made sense.

Yeah it’s a good question and I should’ve clarified. Each of the 13 national quantum centers have a leading national labs, several partner institutions (universities) and then at least 3-4 industry (commercial) partners. 

So commercial partners are involved with every quantum center as far as I’ve seen. 

For example, Q-NEXT at Argonne is partnered with industry partners IBM, Intel, Boeing, Verizon and ColdQuanta to name a few. 

QSA (Berkeley) is partnered with Google, IBM and QED-C. 

SQMS (Fermilab) is partnered with Rigetti, Lockheed Martin, Janis and Goldman Sachs.

C2QA (Brookhaven) has IBM mainly, and then nearly all the Ivy League schools. 

It goes on.
